question_text: Look at this rectangular prism. If all three dimensions are tripled, then which of the following statements about its surface area will be true?
backend_description: Shows a rectangular prism with dimensions 5 cm x 9 cm x 6 cm. Students need to determine how the surface area changes when all dimensions are tripled.
question_type: Multiple Choice Question with Single Answer
choices: The new surface area will be 1/4 of the old surface area.
The new surface area will be 16 times the old surface area.
The new surface area will be 3 times the old surface area.
The new surface area will be 9 times the old surface area.
solution_image_tag: Shows the surface area formula calculation for the new prism with tripled dimensions: S' = 2[(3l)(3w) + (3l)(3h) + (3w)(3h)] = 2[9lw + 9lh + 9wh] = 18(lw + lh + wh).
Shows the ratio calculation: new surface area / original surface area = 18(lw + lh + wh) / 2(lw + lh + wh) = 9. This proves the new surface area is 9 times the original.
solution: You can solve this problem without using the measurements given in the diagram.

The original rectangular prism had the following surface area:
S = 2(lw + lh + wh)

The new rectangular prism will have 3 times the length, 3 times the width, and 3 times the height. Since the original dimensions were l, w, and h, the new dimensions will be 3l, 3w, and 3h. Re-calculate the surface area.
Divide the new surface area by the original surface area and simplify.
The new surface area will be 9 times the old surface area.

question_text: Look at this box. If all three dimensions are quadrupled, then which of the following statements about its volume will be true?
backend_description: Shows a box with dimensions 5 cm x 13 cm x 8 cm. Students need to determine how the volume changes when all dimensions are quadrupled.
question_type: Multiple Choice Question with Single Answer
choices: The new volume will be 1/64 of the old volume.
The new volume will be 64 times the old volume.
The new volume will be 4 times the old volume.
The new volume will be 16 times the old volume.
solution: You can solve this problem without using the measurements given in the diagram.

The original box had the following volume:
V = l x w x h

The new box will have 4 times the length, 4 times the width, and 4 times the height. Since the original dimensions were l, w, and h, the new dimensions will be 4l, 4w, and 4h. Re-calculate the volume.
V' = (4l) x (4w) x (4h) = 64lwh = 64V.

Divide the new volume by the original volume and simplify.
64lwh / lwh = 64
